PROCTEXT.PARA: FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-FOURTH PARLIAMENT
The Senate, on 31 May 1985, adjourned to 20 August 1985, unless the President fixed an earlier day of meeting.
Pursuant to the Resolution of the Senate passed on 31 May 1985, the Senate met on Tuesday, 20 August 1985, at 2 p.m.
His Excellency Air Marshal Sir James Rowland, Administrator of the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia, entered the chamber and, taking his seat on the dais, said:
I am present to administer to senators elected to serve in the Senate from 1 July 1985 the oath or affirmation of allegiance as required by section 42 of the Constitution.
The Clerk produced and laid on the table the Certificates of Election for the following senators to serve in the Senate for the respective States from 1 July 1985:
New South Wales-Kerry Walter Sibraa; Bruce Kenneth Childs; John Joseph Morris; Michael Ehrenfried Baume; Colin Victor James Mason.
Queensland-Margaret Reynolds; Ronald Leslie Doyle Boswell; David John MacGibbon; Gerry Norman Jones; Michael John Macklin.
South Australia-Nick Bolkus; Baden Teague; Graham Maguire; Donald Scott Jessop; Rosemary Anne Crowley.
Tasmania-Brian Archer; John Watson; John Coates; Michael Townley; Norm Sanders.
Victoria-Olive Zakharov; Alan Joseph Missen; Robert Ray; David John Hamer; John Royston Siddons.
Western Australia-Patricia Jessie Giles; Noel Ashley Crichton-Browne; Peter Francis Salmon Cook; Reginald Greive Withers; Josephine Vallentine.
The abovenamed senators made and subscribed the oath or affirmation of allegiance.
His Excellency the Administrator having retired-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Cumming Thom, I remind the Senate that the time has come when it is necessary for the Senate to choose one of its members to be President. I propose to the Senate, for its President, Senator Douglas McClelland. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senator McClelland do take the chair of the Senate as President.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Grimes

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Cumming Thom, I second the motion.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Clerk-Are there any further nominations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Cumming Thom, I propose to the Senate, for its President, Senator Don Jessop, and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senator Jessop do take the chair of the Senate as President.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Durack

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Cumming Thom, I second the motion.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Clerk-Are there any further nominations? There being no further nominations, I invite the two candidates to address the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Clerk, I submit myself to the will of the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Jessop

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Clerk, I also submit myself to the will of the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Clerk-There being two nominations, in accordance with the Standing Orders a ballot will be held. Before proceeding to ballot, the bells will be rung for three minutes.
The bells having been rung-

The Clerk-The Senate will now proceed to ballot. Ballot papers will be distributed to honourable senators, who are requested to write upon the paper the name of the candidate for whom they wish to vote. The Clerks will now distribute ballot papers to all honourable senators. The candidates are Senator Douglas McClelland and Senator Jessop.
A ballot having been taken-

The Clerk-I announce the result of the ballot as follows: Senator Douglas McClelland, 41 votes; and Senator Jessop, 32 votes. Senator Douglas McClelland is therefore elected President of the Senate in accordance with the Standing Orders.
Senator Douglas McClelland having been conducted to the dais-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for bestowing upon me once again the responsibilities of this high office. With the frustrations that I have had over the last 2 1/2 years I wondered at times whether I wanted the position or not, but when it came to the crunch I really fought hard for it. I assure you that over the last 2 1/2 years I have become very conscious and acutely aware of the responsibilities of office. I look foward to working with all my senatorial colleagues for the betterment of the Senate, the Parliament and Australia.

—Mr President, may I be the first to congratulate you on your preferment to the position of President. I must say that I did very little lobbying for the position. I have no doubt that you will discharge the duties in the manner in which you have in the past. I look forward to acting as your deputy in the same friendly spirit as in the past and wish you well in your very eminent position.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would very much like to congratulate you personally on your election as President for a further term, and I am sure I speak for my colleagues. Since you were previously elected President of the Senate I think you have conducted proceedings in this chamber with great dignity. In an alliterative frame of mind a minute or two ago I noted that I thought you had conducted proceedings with fairness, firmness and flair. My lack of alliterative imagination prevents me from going on to use further and similar adjectives. Mr President, I wish you every success. I hope and believe that you will continue to conduct the Senate in the way in which you have in the past.

—Mr President, on behalf of the Opposition I extend our congratulations to you on your re-election as President. I have done a very quick calculation. On my guess, you received the votes of all of the Liberals and Nationals but one, and the Right faction of the Australian Labor Party to get your very impressive result. In that sense we are very pleased to see you restored to your position. Mr President, I agree that you have been a firm and fair President. The Opposition, of course, in particular looks to the President for the protection of its rights and privileges, as do individual honourable senators. I believe we have been able to look to you in the past with great confidence and we will do so again in the future. Mr President, we wish you well for a very happy tenure in this place.

—Mr President, on behalf of my Party and myself I extend our sincere congratulations on your re-election. In the 25 years of my time in both this chamber and the other place I have served under several Presiding Officers. I say with deep sincerity, sir, that no fairer person has presided over the chamber of which I was a member. There has been no one more courageous and more impartial than you. Unlike many of your predecessors, you have presided over a Senate which has not been easy at all times. In the last few years you have presided over a Senate in which very heavy questions have been debated and settled. You have done that with impeccable impartiality, for which we thank you.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia I would add my congratulations to those which have already been put down by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). As has been said, Mr President, you have served with distinction in the high office which you now hold. I am sure you will continue to do so. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) remarked on the dignity with which you hold that office. I am quite sure that there are times when you wish that we would reciprocate. Be that as it may, this is not a Sunday school picnic; that is the nature of this chamber. Sir, you do have the respect of all of us. We appreciate the impartiality with which you hold your office and with which you preside over this chamber. Speaking on behalf of my National Party colleagues, I can assure you that we will abide by most of the Standing Orders most of the time.

—The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) was somewhat astray in his figures; I can assure him of that. Of course, being President of the Senate means more than sitting in that chair. Mr President, you have an enormous responsibility for both the staff and the running of this place, and also in relation to the challenges that I believe will confront this chamber from governments of all complexions in the future; that is to say, in relation to the independence of the Parliament from the Executive Government. As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, I am aware that you are well across those matters which are of great importance for the future of parliamentary democracy. I am confident that you will be able to lead us in those respects. I congratulate you on your election and look forward to working with you for that cause.

—Being a stranger to this place and not experienced in the workings of the Senate, but having heard your praises sung, Mr President, I also congratulate you and wish you well for the term of the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Jessop, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney), the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp), the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Senator Collard), Senator Harradine and Senator Vallentine for the complimentary and laudatory remarks that they have made upon my election for a second term in this high office as President of the Senate. It is the most prestigious position that one can occupy as a parliamentary officeholder. As I said a little earlier, over the last 2 1/2 years in particular I have been made aware of the responsibilities of the office, not only in this chamber but also outside.

INTERJECT.PARA: I assure honourable senators that with the enlargement of this Parliament as at the last election, and as we get closer to our move to the new Parliament House, the responsibilities of the office and the duties attaching to it grow more every day. It is a challenging and responsible role. I look forward to renewing the work that I have been engaged in in the last 2 1/2 years and to receiving the support of my senatorial colleagues.

I pay tribute to the supportive role that was provided to me by the Deputy President of the Senate in the last Parliament, Senator Hamer. He worked ceaselessly and tirelessly in a supportive role. I am grateful to him and I appreciate the assistance he rendered to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform honourable senators that His Excellency the Administrator will be pleased to receive the President and such honourable senators as desire to accompany him in the Senate Opposition party room forthwith.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 2.42 to 3.30 p.m.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to report that, accompanied by honourable senators, I presented myself to His Excellency the Administrator of the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia as the choice of the Senate as its President and His Excellency was pleased to congratulate me upon my election.

INTERJECT.PARA: The President read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Haines was elected deputy parliamentary leader of the Australian Democrats in a national ballot of members which concluded on Friday, 16 August 1985. In the same ballot members saw fit to re-elect me as the parliamentary leader. I pay the highest tribute possible to Senator Mason who, as Deputy Leader of the Party, entered the Senate with me in 1978 and has worked untiringly in Parliament and in the community for the welfare of Australians. I will continue to rely on his wise counsel, active support and warm friendship.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

DEBATE.TITLE: ELECTION OF DEPUTY PRESIDENT AND CHAIRMAN OF COMMITTEES

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now proceed to elect a Deputy President and Chairman of Committees.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The result of the ballot is: Senator Hamer, 37 votes; Senator Tate, 34 votes. I declare Senator Hamer elected Deputy President and Chairman of Committees.

—Mr President, I thank the Senate for the confidence reposed in me. I shall do my best to conduct the proceedings for which I am responsible with fairness, efficiency and impartiality. To you, Mr President, I pledge my support and loyalty.

—I offer my contratulations to Senator Hamer on his election as Deputy President. I am sorry only that this was apparently a non-nuclear issue; the vote might have been closer if Senator Vallentine had come into the chamber! I believe Senator Hamer's election was well justified by his excellent handling of the duties of the Chair over the past session. I am sure no honourable senator would begrudge him the task that he is undertaking on our behalf. His knowledge of the Standing Orders and the rules of procedure is, I think, unparalleled. We are confident of his impartial application of them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also congratulate Senator Hamer and associate myself with the remarks made by my colleague, Senator Tate, although I cannot emulate his joke.

—On behalf of the Opposition I congratulate our colleague Senator Hamer on his election. I would say of him what I said of you, Mr President: He has shown firmness and fairness in the chair. The combination of you and Senator Hamer has been a successful one for the Senate. Senator Hamer has our best wishes and I know that he will act in the Senate in the same fair way as he has acted in the past.

—On behalf of the Australian Democrats I join in the congratulations to Senator Hamer on his election as Deputy President. It was a difficult choice because both candidates are outstanding members of the Senate. In fact, I thought Senator Tate was in with a real chance until you, Mr President, shopped him in your acceptance speech. Senator Hamer has been absolutely outstanding in the way he has conducted the difficult Committee stage on many complex Bills. I wish him well and assure him of our co-operation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I add my congratulations to those already offered to Senator Hamer. Having been in the position of Temporary Chairman of Committees for some time, I know the difficulties under which you, Mr President, and the Deputy President and Chairman of Committees operate. At times it can be the loneliest seat in the place. Senator Hamer has mastered the Standing Orders and has been able to take us through the labyrinth of the Committee stage, which is often long and arduous. Senator Hamer has carried out that duty well and has been able to keep a firm hand on the proceedings. He has also had a knowledge of what has been going on, which is more than I can say for some of us who sit here trying to handle the various Bills.

—Order! I join with my colleagues in congratulating Senator Hamer. As I said earlier, he has been a great backstop to me in my duties. I appreciate the assistance he has given me in my position as President, and I am sure that we will continue that association over the life of this Senate.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Taxation
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth.
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ``windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
1. That the functions of local government involve assessing local demand for services and either providing, or facilitating the provision of, those services;
2. That a transfer of responsibility for the provision of services from one level of government to another must be accompanied by a corresponding transfer of funds;
3. That local government in Victoria is becoming increasingly involved in the planning and provision of human services in particular;

4. That the level of services currently provided by or through local government cannot be maintained, and certainly cannot be increased, if the funds made available to local government through the personal income tax-sharing arrangements are not maintained at the present level;
5. That we are totally opposed to any reduction in the percentage of personal income tax allocated to local government.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the funding of local government without the consent of representatives of local government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Gareth Evans (from nine citizens), Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from nine citizens) and Lewis (from nine citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned have great concern for the further development and research of the IVF programme and express that we are against `Senator Harradine's Bill' Human Embryo Experimental Bill 1985.
The Bill threatens the provisions as a treatment for infertility because it defines as `prohibited experimentation':
1. Any manipulation of a relevant human embryo;
2. Any procedure undertaken on, or involving the use of, a relevant human embryo,

3. The creating of a relevant human embryo in anticipation that the development of the full human potential of the relevant human will be interrupted or of using the embryo, or of having the embryo available for use, in any experimenting by virtue of sub-section (1) shall be deemed to be prohibited experimenting for the purposes of this Act.
4. Willfully destroy a relevant human embryo.
5. Willfully allow a relevant human embryo to die.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 246 citizens) and Puplick (from 112 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned have great concern for further development and research of the IVF program and express that we are against (Senator Harradine's) Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985.
The Bill threatens the provisions of IVF as a treatment for infertility because it defines as prohibited experimentation
(1) any manipulation of a relevant human embryo.
(2) any procedure undertaken on, or involving the use of a relevant human embryo.
(3) creating a relevant human embryo in anticiptation that the development of the full human potential of the relevant human embryo will be interrupted.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embyro Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Human Embryo Experimentation Bill is a retrogressive step which could deprive thousands of couples of the chance to have children. The planned prohibition on experimentation on a human embyro would have the effect of ending the breakthroughs made in the study of infertility.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should seek the prevention of the passage of the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women in 1983, the Government of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that `States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women'.
That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes.

That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promiscuity (The Australian 26.1.85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal health hazards, the operation of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS.

Your petitioners therefore pray: That the Government of Australia having ratified the UN Convention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the Articles of the Convention and request the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.

The petition of the undersigned shows that because it will cause serious harm to the community, the Parliament will not legalise the possession, sale, hire, or supply of any publication or video tape, video disc, slide or any other recording from which a visual image can be produced, which displays degradation of any person, particularly women and children, or animals; scenes of explicit sexual relations showing genitalia detail; acts of violence and sex; sexual perversion such as sodomy, mutilation, child pornography, urolagnia, coprophilia, necrophilia, bestiality; or the use and effect of illicit drug taking; explicit fellatio and cunnilingus; explicit nudity including touching genitalia, erect penis.
Your petitioners pray the Senate, in Parliament assembled that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the Australian Labor Party:
`is committed to the elimination of nuclear weapons and the ultimate achievement of general and complete disarmament' (ALP Platform 1984, 12E);
and will:
promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans' (ALP Platform 1984, 12E.34);

`oppose the development and acquisition of nuclear, chemical, bacteriological or other weapons of mass destruction for Australia's Armed Forces; nor permit any foreign government to station such weapons on Australian soil' (ALP Platform 1984, 121F.41); and
`oppose the storage of nuclear weapons on Australian territory and the staging of operations involving nuclear weapons from Australian territory' (ALP Platform 1984, 121F.48).

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that all Federal representatives of the Labor Government, and Federal representatives of all other political parties including independents, vote for Senator Chipp's Nuclear Weapons Prohibitions Bill 1984, the passage of which would effectively make Australia a nuclear weapons free zone and would leave no doubt as to the present Government's stated commitment to disarmament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we support Senator Chipp's ``Australian Waters (Nuclear Powered Ships and Nuclear Weapons Prohibition) Bill 1984,'' a Bill for an act to prohibit the passage of nuclear-powered ships, and of vessels carrying nuclear weapons, through Australian waters or in the airspace over them, effectively declaring Australia a ``Nuclear weapons free zone''.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that all Senators, regardless of political affiliations, support this Bill. Not just for our sake but for our children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they so wish to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ministry of Peace and Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth and in concern for peace support:

1. a move towards unity, co-operation and peaceful co-existence amongst all peoples of the earth. We pledge our agreement to an immediate bilateral freeze of the development and deployment of all nuclear weapons and to speed negotiations to dismantle all such weapons of mass destruction under the supervision of a neutral peace-keeping force.

2. the establishment of a Ministry for Peace to focus our energies towards non-violent resolution of world conflicts, encouraging our government to pursue its own independent policies in foreign affairs, non-aligned to any one polarity, with the aim of bringing about lasting and peaceful co-existence worldwide.

3. the establishment of a Senate Select Committee on Nuclear Disarmament and Peace to examine and debate all submissions by way of petitions and proposals and to assist in the creation of the Ministry for Peace.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
Peace on earth and goodwill to all humankind.

PETITION.TITLE: Darwin International Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Northern Territory respectfully showeth:
1. That we are deeply concerned that the redevelopment of the Darwin International Airport is not to continue on schedule.
2. That failure to complete the project will do great damage to the Northern Territory's, and Australia's tourism industry.
3. That the north of the Northern Territory will be left with a totally inadequate airport to service its resident population.
4. That general aviation facilities and industry will be adversely affected by failure to continue with the redevelopment.
5. That the RAAF Base in Darwin will be hampered by failure to continue with the redevelopment, which could result in interference with effective defence procedures for the north of Australia.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure the Commonwealth stands by its commitment to complete the redevelopment of Darwin International Airport by the scheduled completion date of 1988.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the honourable members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that `the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Governments failure to act to correct the anomolies in the Assets Test on pensions bring to its notice and due to have effect from the 21 March 1985 the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners, and calls upon the Australian Democrats to support Senator Messner's bill for the abolition of the Assets Test.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the passage of the Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill to repeal the Labor Governments iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Durack (from 20 citizens) and Messner (from 417 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Duty on Old Cars and Parts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth concern for pending proposals to effectively alter the import duties applicable to parts for vehicles 30 years old and older, as from 30th June, 1985. Such proposals will clearly render pursuance of the laudable pastime of restoration of such vehicles, in many families and circumstances, financially unviable.

Persistance with the policy adopted by senior officers of your Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, is anticipated to have a devastating impact upon unemployment in associated industries, and will significantly interfere with the preservation of a major component of our national heritage. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 May I presented a special report of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings relating to the broadcasting of excerpts of the sound recordings of proceedings on Australian radio and television stations. After the presentation of the report the Senate agreed to the authorisation of the broadcasting of excerpts of its proceedings for a trial period under such conditions as were determined by the Committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: Appended to the special report were guidelines governing access by media organisations to the audio signal of proceedings for the purposes of taking excerpts. The Joint Committee subsequently met and considered those guidelines in the light of media comment on their desirability and practicality. As a result the Committee has determined conditions of access which I now table for the information of honourable senators and which, with the leave of the Senate, I will incorporate in Hansard.
The document read as follows-
JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE BROADCASTING OF PARLIAMENTARY PROCEEDINGS
Conditions for granting access to proceedings of the Senate and the House of Representatives for the purpose of recording and broadcasting excerpts

1. Excerpts may be taken from the proceedings of each House (whether or not the proceedings are being continuously broadcast) commencing at the time fixed for the meeting of the House until the adjournment of that House until the next sitting.
2. Excerpts shall be recorded from the audio signal of proceedings transmitted by the House monitoring system throughout Parliament House, Canberra.
3. Excerpts are not to be used for the purposes of satire or ridicule.
4. Excerpts shall not be used for the purposes of political party advertising or in election campaigns.
5. Fairness and accuracy and a general overall balance should be observed.
6. Excerpts must be placed in context. Commentators should identify Senators and Members at least by name.
7. Unusual events in the galleries should not be given undue emphasis.
8. Qualified privilege only shall apply to broadcasters in the use of excerpts.
9. The instructions of the President of the Senate, and the Speaker of the House of Representatives or their delegated representatives on the use of recorded excepts, shall be observed at all times.
10. Where the excerpts are used on commercial networks, the station should try to ensure that advertising before and after excerpts is of an appropriate nature.
11. Where the audio excerpts of proceedings are used on television, their use may be that of audio over still frames, or overlay material.
12. Access to proceedings for the purpose of recording excerpts shall be on the basis of an understanding to observe these guidelines.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The conditions as determined represent some modification of the original guidelines. Honourable senators should be aware that as well as allowing excerpts to be taken from those proceedings normally available for broadcasting, the Committee has determined that excerpts may also be taken from the adjournment debates and proceedings after 11.30 p.m. which are not currently broadcast. The guidelines now also specify that excerpts are not to be used for the purposes of political party advertising or in election campaigns and that qualified privilege only shall apply to broadcasters.

INTERJECT.PARA: Another modification is that the fortnightly return which was previously required to be provided to the Committee by media organisations is no longer a requirement for access to the audio signal. Alternative monitoring arrangements have been entered into and I will report to the Senate on the monitoring at the conclusion of the trial period. I remind honourable senators of the resolution of the Senate of 27 May 1985 authorising the recording for later broadcasting of excerpts of the proceedings of the Senate from the commencement of proceedings today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to ask you a question.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wonder what `qualified privilege' means in the terms of what you have just announced, bearing in mind the varying differences in the meaning of `qualified privilege' amongst the States of Australia. I wonder whether we could perhaps have some further elaboration at some future date to assist those who may be involved. There are differences in relation to State defamation law and the meaning of `qualified privilege' does differ.

—Order! I am not able to provide Senator Peter Rae with an immediate answer to the question that he asked. However, I think, from recollection, the Committee did receive legal advice on this subject. I shall make appropriate inquiries and advise the Senate accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is the first time that I have seen the statement that has just been made by the President. I do not know whether that is my fault or somebody else's. However, I must say that the statement differs somewhat from what was proposed. When I was coming into the chamber I understood the President to say that it is now proposed that audio excerpts of proceedings can be taken from adjournment debates. I had not understood that that was a recommendation of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings. Normally speaking, adjournment debates, fortunately or unfortunately, are coloured by local matters and are interspersed with names. I know that on a number of occasions in the last Parliament considerable exception was taken to names being used in the adjournment debate by at least one honourable senator. That honourable senator had a perfect right to raise the questions that he did. Indeed, he raised those questions time after time. Honourable senators will recall that he named persons in the Public Service who were not in a position to defend themselves. Again, I do not question the right of any honourable senator to raise matters such as those in the adjournment debate. I might question the prudence of doing so but I do not question their right.

I feel that we should have another look at whether we should agree to allow audio excerpts to be taken of adjournment proceedings. I acknowledge the point that Senator Peter Rae has made. However, statements could be made which may not be libellous under any law of the Commonwealth but may require some answering. Yet, people named in adjournment debates may not be able to respond because of the nature of their employment. In such cases, I believe some consideration should be given by the Senate to the appropriateness of allowing such audio excerpts of the proceedings to be made without some sort of control.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aren't people also named in ordinary debates on broadcast days?
—That is a valid point; I was just coming to that. It is true that in fact there is opportunity in the Senate for any honourable senator to name anybody at any stage of a debate.
—And on broadcast days.
—And on broadcast days. However, I cannot recall such a situation occurring under normal circumstances on a broadcast day.
—It has.

—Senator Georges says that it has. I make the point that normally speaking the adjournment debate is utilised by members of Parliament, as part of their express representative function, for constituents. This is a new question to which, I should point out, I have not given mature consideration. I feel that perhaps time should be given to the Senate to consider this matter before it becomes a fait accompli.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I just want to make a couple of comments. I agree with Senator Harradine that the Senate should move to take note of your statement because I think it is an important statement which announces a further step to be taken to open up this Parliament to the media. On previous occasions I have expressed a view, with which I think you are in broad agreement, that it is in the interests of this Parliament that we should as far as possible be as open to the electronic media as we are to the print media. It is something of an accident of history that whereas the rules which apply to newspapers and which give them ready access to anything that is said, during ordinary debate or the adjournment debate, and it is available and can be used in the print media anywhere, there have been very strong restrictions on the use--
—The adjournment debate is generally too late to be printed.

—The same rules apply to debate on the adjournment. In any event, Mr President, in fact the sorts of problems that have been raised by Senator Harradine arise in just the same way with respect to newspaper publication. Whilst I think it is important that we examine these matters, I would simply wish to welcome the fact that the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings is in fact taking this Parliament to a point where it is more accessible to the Australian public.

SPEECH.PARA: The present position, as I understand it, is that the readership of newspapers is declining. People are placing less reliance on the printed word and more reliance on the electronic media. I think it is absurd to exclude the Parliament from that electronic media. I certainly welcome the fact that the Committee is experimenting in this way. I am sure that all of us will watch with great interest the monitoring that the Committee undertakes. However, in light of the doubts that have been raised, I wish to express my general support for the direction which the Committee is taking.

On the face of it, I think the point raised by Senator Peter Rae is one on which we need to be advised. However, again it would seem to me that the problem which he adverts to is a problem which could arise with respect to news- papers as well as the electronic media. There are variations in the law of defamation from State to State. The best endeavours of Senator Durack and Senator Gareth Evans seem fated not to produce a uniform defamation law in Australia, and I do not think we will ever get a perfect solution because of that lack of uniformity.

Mr President, I would not wish the questions which have been raised to leave an impression that there is not support for the general thrust of the Committee's report. Although the Opposition has not had a chance to discuss that matter formally, it was certainly reported to our party room. On a personal basis, I express my broad satisfaction with what is proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I support the guidelines as tabled by you this afternoon. If I recall correctly the proceedings of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, it was acknowledged that the member or senator had absolute privilege on whatever was said within the Parliament. However, privilege so far as the broadcaster or rebroadcaster is concerned depends on the context of the material and the degree of excerpting or additional wording that occurs down the line. It may be recalled that in the guidelines further editing by rebroadcasters was permitted so long as it complied with the other guidelines in relation to balance, the requirement that proceedings should not be held to ridicule, and so on. I believe that the recommendations, which will be followed during this session, will bring this Parliament into line with what happens in the United Kingdom. Currently the British Broadcasting Corporation can excerpt items from the House of Commons. I think it is necessary to open up parliamentary debates to a wider area of activity and interest within the community. I commend the guidelines to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I desire to speak very briefly because you, Mr President, will be making a further statement on this matter. Generally, I support what the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, and Senator Watson have said; it is a very good thing for this to happen. SPEECH.PARA: Qualified privilege only shall apply to broadcasters in the use of excerpts.

I believe that guideline is capable of two alternative meanings. DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF FORMER SENATOR DAME DOROTHY TANGNEY

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 1 June 1985 of former Senator Dame Dorothy Tangney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 1 June 1985, of Dame Dorothy Tangney, DBE, Senator for the State of Western Australia from 1943 to 1968, places on record its appreciation of her long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to the members of her family in their bereavement.

Dorothy Tangney was born in 1911, a member of a family of nine children. Her father was an engine driver and she was brought up in poor circumstances. She won a State secondary scholarship which paid for her attendance at Saint Joseph's College in Fremantle for five years secondary schooling. On matriculation she combined school teaching and part time study to complete a BA degree at the University of Western Australia. She continued as a post-graduate student to take a diploma of education.

As a teacher Dorothy Tangney taught in the heart of the Fremantle industrial area during the Depression years, where she saw the effects of depressed shipping activities on the families of the waterfront workers. She witnessed hardship, poverty and social deprivation amongst the people and children of that city. These experiences as a person very interested in social issues led her to an interest in politics. She became an active member of the Australian Labor Party and contested a State parliamentary seat in 1936 and 1939. She was placed on the Federal Senate ticket in 1940, and in 1943, although she was in fourth position on the ticket, there was a landslide which saw all four ALP candidates elected. As a result she was the first woman to take a seat in the Australian Senate. She headed the Western Australian Senate ticket for the Labor Party until 1967, the first woman to do so for a major political party.

From the perceived wisdom of 1985 it is probably difficult for us to imagine the challenges which being the first woman senator imposed on Dorothy Tangney. She bore an enormous responsibility. As one of her colleagues said in this place on her retirement, it is a tribute to the success with which she carried out her duties as a senator that other political parties said:
If women can do as splendid a job as Dorothy Tangney we had better also be represented by women in the Senate.

Dorothy Tangney was a strong advocate of governments taking responsibility in respect of social services, education and recognition of the social problems of deserted wives, civilian widows and war widows. Between 1943 and 1946 she was a member of the Joint Committee on Social Security established by the Chifley Labor Government. Much of her most valuable work was accomplished through serving on that Committee. The Committee's recommendations on such matters as child endowment and hospital benefits had all become law by the time she left the Parliament. Another notable contribution was her membership of the Council of the Australian National University from 1951 until her retirement in 1967. Again, she was the first woman member of the Council of the ANU and the only one for many years.

In 1967 Dorothy Tangney was created a Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire. Her parliamentary achievements were also recognised when in 1974 the new Federal seat in Western Australia was named Tangney. She retired from active politics in 1968. She did so in an atmosphere in which colleagues of all parties in the Senate and the House of Representatives praised her work, her sense of humour and wit and her considerable achievements as the first woman senator. She was a long-standing and respected member of the Senate. On behalf of the Government I extend to her family our sincere sympathy at the passing of a fine Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition and also personally I support the motion of condolence which has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and his comments. The late Dame Dorothy Tangney is warmly remembered in my State of Western Australia. There was a great deal of pride in the fact that she was the first woman to enter the Senate. My first knowledge of her was at the University of Western Australia. She was in fact identified primarily as the President of the Societies Council in 1936, which was just before she went into Parliament, and then as the first woman senator; but certainly she was remembered with great regard and affection at that place. I met her when she was serving as a senator and soon learned that she was very well and warmly regarded across the political spectrum. The members of parliament such as my father and Peter Sim from the Senate had a great affection and regard for her.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that in everything that has been written and said about her there are some very consistent threads which have been touched on by the Leader of the Government and which I would like to touch on again. In the speeches which were made on her leaving this place there was a series of tributes in this chamber. Said of her were things such as:
All I can say to you, Dorothy-
I notice that everybody referred to her as Dorothy-
is that you have a warm heart and soul that everybody appreciated. It did not matter whether they were Labor, Liberal, Communist, Country Party, or who they were-you fought their fight for them.
It was said elsewhere by Dame Annabelle Rankin that her first meeting with her predecessor was when Dorothy Tangney came up to her in the Library and said:
`I am Dorothy Tangney. Can I do anything to help you?' Dame Annabelle said that has been her story all through her life.

I will not go through all of the appropriate things that were said at that time, but I was struck by the quotation, which has been used by the Leader of the Government, that she did, indeed, provide an example which many others felt they wished to follow. We certainly have many examples of that in the Senate today.

In one sense I think Dorothy Tangney was of a totally different era in politics. Before her retirement she said: `I have never been a left winger or a right winger. Those terms were non-existent when I joined the Labor Party. I am just a Labor-ite'. But I think she came from another era in other respects as well. I think relationships were a little easier in much of her time in parliament, although she went through that very difficult period of the split. But, in fact, across party lines relationships were a little easier. I think she was a very good example of a person who had very clear lines of communication both within her own party and across to the other side. She was from another era. I make an intentional pun; in a sense, she was pre-era. She did not have the benefit of any equal rights legislation; she simply got out there and did it in circumstances which were extremely difficult. She sacrificed a great deal in her early life in the support of her large number of brothers and sisters.

Again, I will not take the time of the Senate to read the speech, but I think anyone who wants a glimpse of the sorts of qualities which were referred to by the Leader of the Government could take the time to read her own farewell speech to the Senate. I think it is a witty and self-deprecating speech which few of us could emulate. It does give some measure of the woman. In recent years she suffered ill-health. My most recent recollection of her is the weekly references to her in the church bulletin where she was mentioned among those prayed for as the sick of the parish. That was for a very lengthy period. It was, in a sense, an unfortunate end to a long, productive and energetic life. On behalf of the Opposition I extend my sympathy to her surviving family and express the admiration of us all for the way she broke new ground. I thought that the newspaper in her home town stated something which most Australians would like to read of someone who had served in high office in the national parliament. It stated:
The daughter of an engine driver, Dorothy Tangney spent much of her childhood in timber mill towns . . .
She won her education through scholarships and . . . once sold lottery tickets at the Victoria Quay wharf gate so that she could afford to take up a scholarship at a secondary school.
She started her career as a teacher after working to help her family of eight brothers and sisters by day and studying at night.
It is through careers such as that that we are reminded of how much can be achieved by an individual who starts with few advantages but is prepared to make a very great effort.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the Australian Democrats with the motion of condolence moved by Senator John Button and supported by Senator Fred Chaney on behalf of the Opposition. I knew Senator Dame Dorothy Tangney only slightly but I did know that she was a kindly, humble woman who spread humour and inspiration everywhere she went. I join with other speakers in expressing condolences and sympathy to her family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the members of the National Party of Australia in the Senate with the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). Senator Tangney was obviously a trail blazer for the women of Australia in many ways, not in the least-as has been alluded to-in her being the first woman in these hallowed halls. She represented women, her party and the people of Australia, in particular Western Australia, so well here, as has been indicated by those who have spoken before me. It is fitting that a person of her high stature in this community should be so remembered. I wish to be associated with all that has been said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of Senator Coleman, who I know would wish to speak to this motion of condolence, I will speak briefly about the career of Dorothy Tangney who, as has already been mentioned, was certainly an inspiration to those of us who have worked within the Australian Labor Party and, I suspect, to women in other political parties over the last 40 years. As little more than an schoolgirl herself, Dorothy Tangney discovered that her students were desperately hungry and that their lassitude, listlessness and inattention were the result of malnutrition. She decided then to become a parliamentarian and to put a stop to such misery and destitution. After several attempts she gained preselection and was elected to the Senate in 1943, the year in which both the Senate and the House of Representatives welcomed their first elected women. The portraits of these two women, Senator Dorothy Tangney and Dame Enid Lyons, hang in Kings's Hall. They are now in the light and out from behind the pillars behind which they languished for so many years until the sudden explosion of women parliamentarians of the 1980s insisted that the portraits of our two courageous pioneer women be suitably displayed.

SPEECH.PARA: It must have taken great courage and stamina to be a Western Australian senator, male or female, for the 25 years of Dorothy's parliamentary career. In 1968, the last year of her term, she talked about the early trips to Canberra by train. She talked about the time used to get to know Canberra well and to get down to preparation for parliamentary work. For some, this would have been a fairly leisurely existence, but not for a women of Dorothy's calibre and commitment, with a massive agenda of social reforms and the determination to argue for her causes at every possible opportunity.

Her parliamentary career encompassed a generation but it was only for the first six years of those 25 that the Labor Party was in government. Dorothy was proudest of what she called the golden years of social services in this country, the years from 1943 to 1946, during which, despite the crippling effects of war, the community mood was sensitised to social needs and the role of the Federal Government in satisfying those needs. In the Address-in-Reply debate in 1968 she said: `I see that all the things for which I had worked are now accomplished.' She listed achieving government responsibility for and building up a public consciousness of the need for adequate social services; Commonwealth assistance in education; recognition of the rights of ex-service men and women; and recognition of deserted wives, civilian widows and war widows. Among the many other issues on which she fought successful campaigns were the virtual eradication of tuberculosis as a common and, in the 1940s, a frequently fatal infectious disease; persuading governments and the community to take a non-punitive approach to mental illness; the establishment of the Australian National University; and the need for a naval base in Western Australia, which was an issue on which she haunted-her words-successive Ministers for 15 years. Senator Tangney also argued frequently for a national disaster fund and on one occasion fell foul of the President of the Senate who thought she was alluding to a gentleman in another place when she described a `cock-eyed Bob', which is Western Australian vernacular for a localised very destructive storm.

Dorothy was the only woman in the Senate for four years and the only Labor Party woman in the Senate for the 25 years of her term. She was, however, joined by three conservative women within the next decade in the Senate. We who have had the support and the companionship of our female colleagues can only speculate about the loneliness of all those years, all those train trips, the frustration of years in opposition and the fearsome responsibility of being one of the very few women in Federal Parliament, required to fulfil all the expectations of Australian women and also to reassure continually all those doubting men of her capacity for the job. We who now represent our respective parties in the Senate, the House of Representatives and the State parliaments are very well aware of the debt that we owe to Dorothy, whose energy and great talents were given so generously to her constituency and to parliamentary duties without a thought for the heavy cost to her well-being.

Despite ill-health after her retirement, Dorothy maintained her interest in politics and her delightful sense of humour. She often recounted how she had served under six Prime Ministers and seven Governors-General. Until she entered the Senate, the Labor Government did not have a majority in either House but she insisted that she had newspaper articles to prove that at that time she was regarded as the Labor Government's slender majority. She would, I believe, have been highly amused by an incident which occurred during her funeral. I had been requested to represent the President of the Senate at her funeral, including acting as a pall bearer, and was honoured to do so. However, when I lined up with the other pall bearers the funeral director could not cope. He politely but firmly turned me down with the words: `You go back there with the other ladies. This is an all-men affair'. That there are few all-men affairs left in Australian public life is, in no small measure, due to the parliamentary career of this outstanding woman. We honour and celebrate the memory of Dorothy Tangney, pioneer, crusader and senator-a great inspiration to us all.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I support the remarks made with regard to John England. Like many other Northern Territorians I knew John England and his wife, Polly, very well. DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR J. R. ODGERS CB, CBE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform the Senate of the death, on 30 July 1985, of Mr James Rowland Odgers, Clerk of the Senate from 1965 until his retirement in 1979. Mr Odgers served the Parliament, and in particular the Senate, for some 42 years, He commenced duty with the Senate in 1942, having previously worked with the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, and subsequently the Joint House Department, from 1937. In 1953, he produced the first edition of Australian Senate Practice, which is now in its fifth edition.

INTERJECT.PARA: In 1959, Mr Odgers undertook a three-month study of the United States Senate and its committee system, and the widely accepted and effective committee system of this Senate owes a lot to the application of that knowledge by Mr Odgers.
