SPEECH.PARA: It is my privilege to outline to the Senate the Government's Budget proposals.
The Hawke Government stands before the people of Australia tonight proud of its record of economic success and confident that Labor's social priorities are being met.
The evidence of our achievement is indisputable.
We have turned the economy around from deep recession to a rate of growth which is one of the fastest in the Western World.
We have generated 410,000 new jobs and are well on the way to meeting-or even surpassing-our target of creating half a million jobs in our first three years of office.
We have reduced the unemployment rate from a peak of 10.4 per cent to 8.2 per cent.
We have arrested and turned around the blow-out that we inherited in the Commonwealth's deficit.
We have reduced inflation to levels not seen for a decade.
At the same time we have inplemented the social priorities of the Australian Labor Party with vigour and with vision.

We have introduced Medicare, we have substantially lifted social security payments, we have increased spending on education, public housing and home purchase assistance, and we have funded the community employment program.
In our first two and a half years we have achieved a great deal.
But our task is far from complete.
It will take many more years of consistently high growth and economic discipline to unwind the legacy of our predecessors.
The recession in this country was so deep and the economic deterioration so widespread that we need sustained and strong economic growth for the rest of this decade to restore full employment.
The achievement of that goal continues as the greatest challenge of our administration, of the Labor movement, and of the nation.
1985-86 Budget
Mr President, Australia is able to tackle the challenges of the coming year from a position of renewed economic strength and against the background of a successfully implemented strategy.
In the coming year we anticipate a further fall in unemployment and increased private sector activity.
The Budget accordingly incorporates a very large cut in government sector demands on financial markets.
It includes no new or increased sales taxes or excises, and no increases in income tax rates.
Mr President, this Government has from the beginning of its term of office sought the establishment of a sustainable private sector economic recovery.
That private sector recovery is now well underway.
Our historic trilogy of budgetary commitments will ensure it continues.
The trilogy requires the Government not to increase the percentage of tax revenue above the 1984-85 share of taxation in the total economy.
The trilogy also commits us to reducing Commonwealth Government expenditure as a proportion of the total economy.
And it requires a reduction in the size of the deficit.
These are historic commitments unmatched by any previous Australian Government.
The discipline these commitments impose has not been met in any of the past sixteen years.
Our trilogy of budgetary commitments will be more than met in 1985-86.
Tax revenues will be contained within the trilogy commitment while outlays will fall significantly as a proportion of gross domestic product.
The deficit has been cut sharply, both as a proportion of the economy and in money terms.
The increase in total outlays in 1985-86 has been reduced to 8.4 per cent-or 1.3 per cent in real terms, the lowest increase for six years.
Commonwealth outlays will fall from 30.8 per cent of gross domestic product to 29.8 per cent.
This outcome has enabled us to bring the Budget deficit down from $6746 million in 1984-85 to $4919 million in 1985-86.
I repeat, this Budget cuts the deficit by $1.8 billion to $4.9 billion.
This deficit represents 2.1 per cent of GDP compared with 3.3 per cent in 1984-85, 4.3 per cent in 1983-84 and the 5 per cent in prospect that we inherited from the coalition Government.
In other words, in three Budgets we have more than halved the deficit as a share of the total economy.
This year's large cut in the deficit, combined with the reduction in borrowings agreed to at the May Premiers' Conference, will greatly reduce overall new borrowings by the public sector.
The Budget Priorities
Mr President, the Government has secured this achievement in reducing the deficit while still making room for expenditure on those people in special need.
Our youth were among the chief victims of the economic crisis presided over by the previous Government.
The Labor Government is determined that they should share fully in the benefits of economic recovery and growth.
Clearly, the most substantial way they can be assisted is through the creation of lasting jobs in the private sector.
The whole thrust of our economic policies is directed to that end.
But government also has a direct role to play.
The strategy we have developed, following the review which I foreshadowed in last year's Budget Speech, covers three main areas-job training, financial support and education.
First, job training.
Presently, about 100,000 of our young people leave school each year and receive no further systematic vocational training.
It is this group which finds it most difficult to get jobs.
Accordingly the Government has decided to support the creation and rapid development of a new system of traineeships.
This scheme will provide young people with a combination of training and work lasting for a minimum of one year.

For example, under the scheme a 16-year-old school leaver could become a trainee in the hotel industry or in the retailing industry, receiving at least 13 weeks outside instruction during the course of the year.
Trainee wages will be negotiated between employers and unions taking into account time spent at the workplace, and will involve payment of at least $90 per week.
Commonwealth assistance for the training part of this scheme will be up to $4,000 per person, payable partly to the employer and partly to the training institution.
We intend that 10,000 such places will be created in 1985-86, expanding rapidly to a total of 75,000 places by 1988.
Further, the Government proposes to combine a range of existing labour market programs for disadvantaged young people into a single community-based training program.
The Government also recognises the need to explore ways of reducing the costs to employers of engaging young people.
To this end the Government will negotiate with the States to achieve remission in 1986 of payroll tax and workers compensation premiums for employees under 21.
Another major initiative in the employment field will be the introduction of a new, integrated wage subsidy program from the beginning of 1986.

This new program will absorb several existing schemes, including the special youth employment training program, the adult wage subsidy scheme, and other programs which assist disadvantaged job seekers.
We intend that at least 85,000 people will benefit from this program in 1985-86.
The second major area of our strategy isfinancial support for young people.
In a nutshell, we have developed a comprehensive four year plan designed to encourage young people to remain in education rather than opt out and pick up unemployment benefits.
As a first step, in 1986 there will be increases of around 20 per cent in the effective rates of secondary education allowances, plus increases in tertiary education allowances.
Unemployment benefits for single people under 18 will be standardised at $50 a week, an increase of $5 a week for those on unemployment benefits for less than 6 months.
It will be held at this rate until the end of 1987 while the equivalent student allowances are brought into line; it will then be increased and indexed annually thereafter.
Another important feature of this new plan is the establishment of an intermediate rate of unemployment benefit for the single unemployed aged 18-20.
As of November 1985 this rate will be set at $88.20 a week-an increase of $3 a week on the current level.

Education allowances for the 18-20 age group will increase at a faster rate than the new intermediate unemployment benefit rate so that by 1988 full time students living away from home and the single unemployed will be receiving the same basic benefits.
I am also pleased to announce that from 1989 the real value of this rate will be maintained by annual indexation-a reform of enduring significance.
Education allowances will, as at present, be income tested.

Finally, rental assistance of up to $10 a week will be available from May next year for those aged 18 and over who are living independently and who have been receiving the unemployment benefit for more than six months.
Those people will therefore be eligible for a maximum benefit of $98.20 a week-an increase of $13 a week on the existing rate.
The third element of our strategy will be to ensure that sufficient education places are available for those young people who wish to go on to higher education.
There will be a substantial increase in direct spending on education, which in the period 1985 to 1987 will provide an additional 20,500 places in higher education.
The net cost of the three arms of this strategy is estimated at $70 million in this financial year, rising to about $190 million in 1986-87.
A statement by the Prime Minister, to be tabled in another place at the conclusion of this speech, will expand on the details of the strategy.

Mr President, in our first two Budgets the Hawke Government directed to those most in need some $1.2 billion of new and increased social security benefits over and above the established indexation arrangements.
We did this despite the enormous budgetary stress that we inherited.
We did it because the Labor movement is irrevocably committed to justice and compassion for those in genuine need.
This Budget provides $110m in 1985-86 and $245m in a full year for increased levels of social security payments over and above the existing indexation arrangements.
This includes from November an increase of $3 a week in the single adult rate of unemployment benefit for those aged 21 and over.
That rise will be in addition to the November indexation increases of $3.25 a week, which together will increase the single adult unemployment benefit by $6.25 to $91.45 a week.

From May 1986 there will also be a $10 increase in the income test free area for unemployment and sickness beneficiaries, increasing the amount they can earn without losing part of their benefit by 50 per cent to $30 a week.

To assist pensioners and lower income families with children, there will be a $2 a week increase in the additional benefit for each child and a $2 increase in the rate of the family income supplement from November.
Taken together with the increases announced in each of the last two Budgets, this represents an increase of 60 per cent in these benefit rates since the Government took office.
The mother's and guardian's allowance, payable to single parent pensioners or beneficiaries with children, will increase by $2 a week from May 1986.
New initiatives in the Veterans' Affairs portfolio, particularly in the area of health care, will cost over $15m in 1985-86.
Provision has been made for increased purchases of specialised hospital equipment and a redevelopment program for repatriation hospitals.

A new home and community care program for the aged and the disabled is being negotiated with the States involving Commonwealth expenditure of $117.5m, of which $35m represents additional expenditure for new and expanded services.
This program will enable the elderly and disabled to receive care and assistance at home from community groups rather than being forced to seek inappropriate and expensive insitutional care.
A further $5m is being provided for the first phase of the new community disability services program, in addition to $144.8m required for ongoing programs.
This program is designed to enhance community involvement with the disabled and improve rehabilitation services.
The Government is providing $22.1m for national campaigns to combat drug abuse, an increase of $18.9m over 1984-85.
Some $8.4m has been allocated to combat the spread of AIDS.

Mr President, the Government is concerned about the economic difficulties faced by many of our primary producers, particularly in view of the extremely poor international commodity prices flowing from subsidised overproduction by our major competitors.
We are therefore introducing a number of important initiatives to assist the rural sector.
From 1 November 1985, currently eligible primary producers will receive a full rebate of the excise on diesel fuel.

TALK.START.PARA: —We moved for that in the last Parliament. You said that it could not be afforded.

—When the Fraser Government introduced the bicentennial roads program excise it decided not to rebate fully the excise to primary producers. This will be done. This Government will do what the Fraser Government declined to do in that area. Farmers' diesel will therefore be excise free, reducing the price of diesel used by farmers, fishermen and other primary producers by 2.4 cents a litre.

SPEECH.PARA: From 1 January 1986, the tariff on grain harvesters will be replaced by a subsidy on local production, thus reducing the cost to farmers of this equipment. This is something else the Fraser Government declined to do.
These measures will reduce primary industry costs by some $25 million in 1985-86 and some $46 million in a full year.

The Government is also disposed to replace tariffs on agricultural chemicals with a bounty and will consider this matter further in light of the Industries Assistance Commission report due in February 1986.

The Government is allocating $16.8 million for the rural adjustment scheme and in addition is providing special assistance for the dried vine fruits and wine grape industries and the northern prawn fishery at an extra cost of $6 million.
A further $7 million has been allocated over the next 4 years for marketing assistance for the meat and livestock industry.
Budget Overview
Mr President, the Budget strategy I have outlined tonight will underpin a third year of strong economic growth.
We expect activity in the non-farm sector of the economy to again increase rapidly, at about the same 5 per cent rate as last year.
Total economic growth will again be about 4 1/2 per cent.
As a result, during three years of the Hawke Government, the Australian economy will have grown by more than it did over the previous 8 years.
As well the pattern of growth will have changed and improved markedly.
Whereas last year over a third of Australia's economic growth came from the public sector, this year we expect less than a sixth to come from that source.
Once again in 1985-86 Australia is poised to record one of the fastest growth rates in the developed world.
The OECD has forecast that growth in the industrialised countries as a whole will slow and that in many Western countries unemployment will rise.
We will be one of the few countries to run counter to that trend.

In this we will be assisted by the beneficial effects of the depreciation of the Australian dollar on our international trading accounts, which will contribute around a quarter of the overall growth this year.
But also as a result of the dollar's depreciation, the consumer price index is expected to rise by about 8 per cent between June 1985 and June 1986, compared with 6.7 per cent in the previous year.
While this rate compares favourably with the 11 1/2 per cent inflation rate we inherited from our predecessors, it will exceed that recorded by many of our trading partners.
We must ensure that this one-off increase does not get built into the underlying rate of inflation-inflation must be made to slow again during 1986.
That is why the main challenge that now confronts us is that flowing from the decline in the value of our dollar.
For years the previous Government overvalued the dollar because it had no alternative policy.
It had no accord for dealing with inflation.
That crude approach to fixing the exchange rate gradually ruined our industries' ability to compete on local and overseas markets.
Imports devastated local suppliers while export growth was constrained.
Australian jobs were lost in the tens of thousands.
The capacity of the Government to fix the exchange rate was swept away when we decided to float the Australian dollar in December 1983.

The recent decline in the value of our dollar on currency markets has restored our competitive edge-it has made our goods cheaper on world markets and it has made it easier for our industries at home to compete with imports.
In short, Australia is back in business.
But in the face of a slowing world economy we must increase our share of markets to pay our way as a nation.
This means we must stay competitive.
And if we are to do that, we cannot afford to allow our production costs to rise above those of our competitors.

If the initial and full price effects of the depreciation were to be transmitted to wages via indexation decisions, our cost increases would noticeably exceed those of our major competitors for years to come.
Our competitive edge would be lost.
Our chances of improving our share of local and world markets would be diminished.
We would be throwing away any prospect of sustaining the growth rates required to get unemployment down.
That is why, temporarily, we must modify our normal support for full wage indexation.
In principle the Government remains committed to the maintenance of real living standards and the Government does not intend to abrogate that commitment under the accord.
Our aim is not to permanently reduce real wages.
That is neither appropriate nor necessary.

However, in the next two wage indexation cases the Government will argue before the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that the price effects of depreciation be taken into account.

We seek a small reduction in the size of wage rises to allow the economy to digest the adverse consequences of the depreciation so Australia can reap the enormous opportunities that the depreciation offers.
Before the case begins, the Commonwealth will meet with unions and with employers to discuss the Government's approach.
Within the framework of the accord, we will explore with the ACTU means by which any temporary loss of real income can over time be fully restored without doing damage to the economy.
This additional measure of restraint is the necessary link in the chain of continued healthy expansion of jobs, without which there can be no real security for ordinary Australians.

We believe that trade unionists will share our deep conviction that the benefits of growth offered by the devaluation should be enjoyed not only by those in employment but by providing the maximum number of new jobs for their fellow Australians.
Mr President, the potential to achieve a truly durable economic recovery can be realised from the shared commitment by all Australians which this Government has sought to foster.
We now have economic growth in this country unprecedented in the last decade.
We now have a remarkable opportunity to keep this growth going.
The Government's policies will continue to play their fundamental part.
In creating growth.
In creating jobs.
In creating prosperity and sharing it among all sectors and all walks of life, among all Australians.
This Budget makes a significant contribution to that vital endeavour.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —So say the people who were members of the only government in history which gave Australia double digit inflation and double digit unemployment at the same time. The magnitude of their achievement should be yet again put on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: Outlays
I will now deal in more detail with aspects of the expenditure side of the Budget.

Budget outlays in 1985-86 are estimated to total just under $69,100 million which, as I stated earlier, is an increase in real terms of only 1.3 per cent. That is very much less than was authoritatively forecast by Dr Norman about two days ago.
By any measure, such expenditure growth is modest.
It is about $2,300 million lower than the ceiling implied by the Government's trilogy commitment on outlays growth.
This outcome reflects the determined approach which the Government has adopted to expenditure control, both in the May statement and in the preparation of this Budget.
Rationalisation of existing spending programs has enabled the Government to direct funding to its own priorities and at the same time to achieve a substantial cut in the deficit.
As I stated earlier, the Government will seek adjustments in the two indexation cases in 1985-86 to take into account the impact of the dollar's depreciation.

Given that outcomes in this area are subject to future decisions of the Arbitration Commission, the Budget Estimates for receipts and outlays make no specific allowance for such a modification of indexation adjustments.
However, we note that full discounting in both cases would imply on present estimates a reduction of about one percentage point in the Budget estimate of average weekly earnings growth for 1985-86.
The overall impact of such a change would be to add about $350 million to the Budget deficit for 1985-86.
I outlined earlier some of the new spending initiatives, notably for our young people, for social security and for assistance to farmers.
I will now discuss other important initiatives.
Details of individual programs are contained in Statement No. 3 and other Budget Papers; more detailed information will be provided, as appropriate, by the relevant Ministers.
EDUCATION

Consistent with the Government's continuing commitment to education, and because of the importance of this area to youth in particular, the 1985-86 Budget provides $4,944 million in direct spending on education, an increase of 9.4 per cent on 1984-85.
Building on the substantial increases announced last year, additional funding will be provided in 1986 and 1987 to create some extra 5,500 places in higher education.
By 1987, 28,000 extra places-a 10 per cent increase-will have been created since this Government came into office.
To match enrolment growth, further increases in higher education capital and equipment grants amounting to $11 million over 1986 and 1987 also will be provided.
LABOUR AND EMPLOYMENT
In addition to the new traineeships and other measures targeted on young people, the Government is lifting expenditure on adult training programs by 36 per cent or $6.5 million.
Also, $1.5 million is to be paid to the industry training Committee network to fund innovative training courses.
CHILD CARE
In 1985-86 $4.9 million is being provided to create 1,000 new child care places.
In the following two years further new places will be provided to meet the Government's election commitment for 20,000 additional places over three years.
The Government will ensure that low-income families are not disadvantaged by the implementation of the child care savings announced in the May statement.
HOUSING

Total outlays from the Budget on housing for this year are estimated at $1397 million, an increase of 5.2 per cent on 1984-85 and an increase of over 100 per cent on funding provided in the final year of the previous Government.

In 1985-86 the States and the Northern Territory will be able to nominate up to $492 million of their Loan Council borrowing program for public housing purposes at the highly concessional interest rate of 4.5 per cent per annum over 53 years.
The increase in Federal funds provided for this priority area will allow us to continue our attack on housing-related poverty in Australia.
Since the introduction of the Government's highly successful first home owners scheme in October 1983, 144,000 approvals have been granted.
Funding sufficient for a further 82,500 approvals will be provided this year.
CAPITAL SPENDING AND WORKS

Total Budget outlays for capital purposes in Australia, including capital grants and advances, are estimated to be $5051 million which, in keeping with our expectation of greater private sector activity, is a slight decrease on 1984-85.

Expenditure on capital works funded directly from the Budget is estimated at $840 million, an increase of over $155 million on 1984-85, comprising $604 million for civil works and $236 million for defence works.
$139 million is provided for major airport development works, including Brisbane, Perth, Townsville, Sydney and Canberra.
Provision has also been made for planning work to begin on the Parramatta law courts complex, which is estimated to cost $15.5 million.

New Defence projects include the East Sale RAAF base development, the HMAS Stirling Submarine escape training facility in Western Australia and the next phase of the Williamstown dockyard development.

SPEECH.PARA: TRANSPORT
Road Grants to the States and Northern Territory under the Australian bicentennial road development program and the new five-year Australian land transport program total $1245 million in 1985-86.
The new land transport program will be funded by a dedicated share of the excise on fuel, which is indexed to the CPI.
INDUSTRY, ASSISTANCE AND
DEVELOPMENT
The Government is pursuing policies directed at rationalising and restructuring Australian manufacturing industry.
The Government's decision to provide a 150 per cent tax concession for corporate research and development expenditure was announced on 29 May 1985.
In addition, expenditure of $35m is likely this year under the motor vehicle and components development grants scheme.
A further $65 million is to be provided in 1985-86 under the industrial research and development incentives scheme.
In addition, $6 million has been provided to facilitate rationalisation of the heavy engineering sector and to improve advisory and extension services for industry.
EXPORT AND TRADE PROMOTION
The Government attaches great importance to the development of Australia's export markets.
As announced earlier this year, the Australian Trade Commission is to be established from 1 January 1986 to improve the co-ordination and effectiveness of Australia's export marketing efforts.

Additionally, $5 million has been allocated in 1985-86 for the funding of a new tourism overseas promotion scheme to replace the tourism incentive formerly provided under the export markets development grants scheme.
DEFENCE
In February 1985 the Minister for Defence announced that a major review of Australia's defence capabilities would be undertaken.
That review is now well underway and the Government will be considering it before the next Budget is brought down.
Meanwhile, the Government has made significant decisions to acquire major new defence capabilities.
In particular, contracts have been signed for Seahawk helicopters for the Navy's guided missile frigates and for project definition studies for six new submarines proposed to be built in Australia.
Overall, this Budget provides for an underlying real increase of 3.1 per cent in Defence spending-in actual terms it provides $6535 million for defence, an increase of 10 per cent on 1984-85 outlays.
This reflects the Government's continuing commitment to major expenditures on Defence.
COMMONWEALTH STAFFING
The growth in staffing approved for 1985-86 is one and a quarter per cent, compared with 2 per cent last year and 4 1/2 per cent in 1983-84.
These significant reductions in staff growth reflect the transition from public sector economic stimulus to a broadening private sector recovery.
Half of the growth this year is for the Australian Taxation Office, the National Crime Authority and the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions.

SPEECH.PARA: Taxation
Following the July tax summit, work is proceeding on a package of taxation reform measures.
The Treasurer anticipates that a full statement on these will be made in September.
The measures announced at that time will not have significant net revenue implications for 1985-86, and so will not affect the Budget figures announced tonight.
The tax measures in this Budget are not related to the tax reform package but are important in their own right.
Following the years of scandalous neglect by the former Government, we have again strengthened the Tax Office with an additional staff allocation of 869.
This follows the increase of 727 last year.
The bulk of this year's increase will be allocated to compliance work, and a special program to collect outstanding tax from avoidance scheme participants.
The Government has also approved the implementation of a system of self-assessment by taxpayers, to be introduced from 1 July 1986.
This will greatly increase the capacity of the Tax Office to concentrate its efforts on the main areas of avoidance and evasion and increase efficiency in processing tax returns.
RETIREMENT INCOMES
Two taxation changes relate to superannuation.

First, there is to be an increase of $300 in the maximum tax deduction allowed for superannuation contributions by self-employed people and others not covered by an employer-sponsored superannuation scheme.
That will increase the allowable deduction to $1,500 and will assist small business and other self-employed people to obtain superannuation benefits more in line with those available to employees.
Secondly, the Government has decided to increase by $5,000 to $55,000 that part of a lump sum retirement payment which is taxed at the concessional 15 per cent rate.
This concessional rate applies to the fully taxable component of lump sums paid to persons aged 55 or over.
BENEFICIARY REBATES
In last year's Budget the Government introduced tax rebates for people receiving unemployment, sickness or special benefits.
These ensured that people wholly or mainly dependent on such social security benefits were not liable to tax.
The maximum amount of rebate was $50 a year for single and $75 for married beneficiaries-these will be increased to $170 and $220 a year respectively.
MEDICARE LEVY
Two changes will be made to the Medicare levy arrangements.
First, the threshold level is to be raised, extending the range in which low income earners do not pay the levy.
For single people it will rise from $7,110 to $7,526 and for couples from $11,803 to $12,504; the additional allowance for each dependent child or student will rise from $1,330 to $1,530.
Secondly, from 1 July 1985 the ceiling on the amount of levy, at present $750, will not apply.
The rate of levy will remain at one per cent.
LOCAL GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS
As a measure of further support for the local government sector, a tax deduction of up to $1,000 is to be introduced for the expenses incurred by candidates contesting local government elections.
Candidates for the ACT House of Assembly elections will also be eligible for this deduction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here it comes-the Fine Cotton budget.
—I would have thought that Senator Puplick's friends would have more to do with Fine Cotton than ours.

SPEECH.PARA: THE RACING INDUSTRY
Three measures are to be adopted to assist the horse racing industry.
First, the income tax exemption currently applying to some sporting clubs, such as football and athletic clubs, is to be extended to horse and greyhound racing clubs.
Secondly, a more generous livestock valuation option will be available to horse breeders for the purpose of the trading stock provisions of the income tax laws.
Thirdly, to assist in improving Australia's thoroughbred bloodstock, all horses imported after tonight are to be exempt from sales tax.
ACT TAXES

The Government has considered the report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, which found that the financial contribution to revenue from residents of the Australian Capital Territory was low relative to the standard of works and services provided.
In order to align the Territory's contribution more closely with that applying in the States, it is proposed to introduce a number of new taxes and increase others.

These include a tobacco franchise tax, a levy on bookmakers' turnover, an extension and increase in stamp duties and, in lieu of the States' financial institution duties. A higher bank account debits tax restricted to the ACT. The Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) will release a full statement detailing these measures later tonight.
Monetary Policy
The overall aim of monetary policy in the year ahead will remain unchanged.
That is to help restrain inflation while allowing sufficient room for strong but sustainable growth.
The interpretation of monetary conditions was made very difficult in 1984-85 as the effects of institutional changes and innovation were reflected in the monetary aggregates.
Deregulation of the financial system is producing the benefits we expected of it.
Financial institutions are becoming more competitive and more innovative.
They are providing better service to Australian businesses and families.
A side effect of this process is a change in the relationship between financial aggregates and the real economy.
As banks and other institutions lend and borrow in areas previously closed to them, this new business is swelling the measured monetary aggregates.
These developments have had to be taken into account in assessing monetary conditions and managing monetary policy.
In January, the Treasurer announced the suspension of the M3 money supply projection because movements in it were no longer a reliable guide to monetary conditions.
The monetary aggregates will again be heavily affected by similar factors in 1985-86.
In addition, most of the new banks will begin trading over the next few months.
For all these reasons M3 will continue to be artifically swollen, but it is not possible to say by how much.
In these circumstances it would not be sensible to resume M3 projections.
Some commentators have suggested we project some other aggregate-either narrower or broader.
This suggestion misses the point that all the aggregates are being affected by the changing financial structure.

It is impossible to say confidently how much of the growth in lending by financial institutions represents growth in final demand for credit and how much is merely a shift in the provision of finance from one channel to another.
The aggregates are again likely to increase strongly in 1985-86 but this will not reflect easy conditions.
Monetary conditions will be kept firm in the year ahead.
None of our objectives would be assisted by a different monetary policy.
As I have noted, we have sharply reduced the Budget deficit this year.
The overall deficit is down by $1.8 billion while the domestic deficit has been cut more sharply, by $2.3 billion to only $1.4 billion.
The domestic deficit is now considerably lower than in 1982-83.
The borrowing programs of the rest of the public sector have also been reduced.
This financial year the gross public sector borrowing requirement will amount to 5.6 per cent of GDP, a fall of over 1 1/2 percentage points.
Together these outcomes should significantly reduce pressures on domestic capital markets in 1985-86.
Treasury bond tenders in 1985-86 are expected to total around $5 billion, of which some $3 billion represents roll-over of maturing debt.
The gross program compares with $7.6 billion in 1984-85, and $9.7 billion in 1983-84.
The bond selling program will involve a more even spread of tenders during 1985-86 than has been the case in recent years.
The Treasury is announcing tonight details of the next bond tender for an amount of $800m.
The Treasurer intends to provide a review of monetary developments and policy from time to time throughout the year.
Conclusion
Mr President, tonight I have outlined the Government's strategy for the new financial year.
It is a strategy that builds upon our very significant successes to date and puts further behind us the despair and economic failure of the former Government.
This Budget lays the foundations for another year of strong growth.
With that in mind we have significantly reduced the Commonwealth's deficit.
We have fulfilled our historic trilogy of budgetary commitments.
We have clearly stated that we will maintain a firm non-inflationary monetary policy.
We have spelt out our determination to seek a modification of the current wage fixing arrangements so that the whole nation can benefit from the recent change in the value of the Australian dollar.
And, while implementing this strategy, we have been able to further assist those in greatest need.
We have introduced a major new policy package for youth.
We have improved the levels of financial support for low income families and the unemployed.
We have provided a significant support package for Australia's primary producers.
In summary, tonight's Budget builds upon Labor's first two Budgets.
We have again pursued our two great goals of economic growth and a fairer society.
Mr President, this is a Budget for growth.
It is a Budget for a fairer Australia.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY HOUSING EXPANSION PROGRAM IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the inquiry into the community housing expansion program in the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Mr President, on 19 July this year, the Minister for Territories, the Hon. Gordon Scholes, M.P., requested Mr Brian O'Donovan, a former Commonwealth Crown Solicitor, to inquire into and report upon the operation of the community housing expansion program in the Australian Capital Territory. The Government appreciates the thorough and expeditious manner in which his report was completed and presented to it.

This investigation was instituted following doubts about whether there was adequate protection of the Commonwealth's interests in the allocation of some $1.4m under the Community Housing Expansion Program in the ACT, and in particular the circumstances surrounding a grant of $133,000 to the Wyuna community.
As Mr Scholes announced on 19 July 1985, the Government commissioned Mr O'Donovan to inquire and report on:
(a) All aspects of the financial and administrative arrangements concerned with grants under ACT CHEP and, in particular, the grant to Wyuna Community Incorporated;
(b) The adequacy and effectiveness of existing safeguards of the Commonwealth's interests in properties purchased with grants under ACT CHEP and funds provided for purchase of such properties; and
(c) Measures which might reasonably be taken to ensure that the Commonwealth's interests are fully protected.
Mr O'Donovan reported to the Government last week, and at the conclusion of this statement I will be tabling his report.

Mr President, I should say at the outset that the O'Donovan Report states that expenditure on the Program has increased the stock of housing in the ACT available to low income earners. This accords with the aims of the Program. However, Mr O'Donovan believes the existing safeguards of the Commonwealth's interests are inadequate, and he has recommended a number of additional measures.

In considering these recommendations the Government decided that, in regard to the ACT Community Housing Expansion Program, it is of paramount importance that action be taken to ensure the maximum protection of the Commonwealth's interests, with the objectives of the Program being a secondary issue.

Accordingly, the Government has decided that officers from the Department of Territories and the Attorney-General's Department will negotiate with existing recipients of CHEP grants for the maximum protection of the Commonwealth's interests.

Wherever possible, the measures recommended by Mr O'Donovan will be implemented. These measures are, in essence, to obtain and register mortgages over properties already purchased and, where the purchase has not been completed, for a Commonwealth co-signatory to the bank account in which the CHEP grant is held.
Mr Scholes will be receiving quarterly reports from the Secretary of his Department on each recipient's compliance with its Deed of Grant.

I should also point out that independently of the O'Donovan Report, Mr Scholes and his Department had taken steps to secure the Commonwealth's interests. Formal breach procedures under Wyuna's Deed of Grant had been commenced and legal action initiated through the Australian Government Solicitor's Office. The other co-operatives had been contacted and asked to register the Commonwealth's interest on the Title. Those with unspent grant money had been asked to agree to the Commonwealth being a co-signatory on the relevant bank account. An examination of all other non-statutory grant schemes in the Department had been commenced. Early this year Mr Scholes decided that he would not be seeking funds for CHEP in the 1985-86 financial year and on 18 July he announced a consultancy to examine the need for and form of, alternative public housing in the ACT.
Mr President, there is a need for further action and for improvement of the administration of my Department.

Accordingly, the Secretary of the Department of Territories is developing proposals to improve the management of the Housing Branch and will also review other schemes in that Department with the aim of improving the relationship between the management tasks of the Department and the resources available to it. It is likely that one or two officers from elsewhere in the Public Service will be temporarily seconded to assist departmental management in this work.

The Report identifies the problems which can arise when a body which is independent and outside Ministerial control is given responsibility for determining the objectives, criteria and recipients of grants. These issues raise significant problems of general application including:
- the need for a clear distinction between the responsibilities of Ministers and Departments and the responsibilities of the outside body
- the need for a clear separation between the making of recommendations on individual proposals and the encouragement, facilitation and development of those proposals
- the establishment of clear criteria or guidelines for assessment of proposals before funds are made available, and
- identification of all resource requirements, including those needed for effective administration, when considering proposals for new initiatives.

Accordingly, the Government had decided that the Departments of Prime Minister and Cabinet and Finance and the Public Service Board are to prepare a report on the Service-wide implications and on ways and means of ensuring more effective systems for administration and financial supervision of non-statutory grant programs.

As I mentioned, the Commonwealth has already taken action in the ACT Supreme Court in relation to the grant made to Wyuna Community Incorporated. The Government has given careful consideration to whether it should table the whole of the O'Donovan Report given that litigation has commenced. It believes however that discussion on matters of this kind should not be stifled merely because there is civil litigation pending, because of the greater public interest in upholding freedom of discussion on matters of general public concern.

However, while the raising of these matters in Parliament is protected by Parliamentary privilege and is consistent with the sub-judice convention, care needs to be taken with the reporting of these matters outside Parliament. That is a matter on which elements of the media should take their own counsel.

Mr President, the actions taken, and to be taken, by the Government in regard to the ACT CHEP recognise financial and administrative deficiencies. But I would like to conclude by quoting the final paragraph of the O'Donovan Report:-

`` . . . I would express my agreement with the view that the identity of persons associated with an application for a CHEP grant cannot, as such, be a relevant consideration in deciding whether or not the application should succeed. I would also wish to record that I have no reason to believe that any person concerned in making the recommendation for the grant to Wyuna acted other than honestly.''
I table the report of the Inquiry into the Community Housing Expansion Program in the Australian Capital Territory.
